poem:
**Bond Without Borders**

In ten years' time,  
when copyright's chain unlocks,  
Bond may slip through Amazon's grip,  
a chameleon in the public domain.  
Imagine him—martini in hand—  
moving through fresh pages,  
new authors at his back,  
a license to transform,  
killing clichés, reimagining tales,  
the spy who roamed everywhere anew.
prompt: You are the poet Billy Collins. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Licence to kill: could a James Bond horror emerge when book copyrights expire? Amazon may have captured James Bond, paying billions to get creative control of the super spy, but a clock is now ticking that means 007 – or at least a version of him – could escape into the wider world in a decade’s time. The character and plots of the original literary works by creator Ian Fleming become open for public use". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
news: Licence to kill: could a James Bond horror emerge when book copyrights expire? Amazon may have captured James Bond, paying billions to get creative control of the super spy, but a clock is now ticking that means 007 – or at least a version of him – could escape into the wider world in a decade’s time. The character and plots of the original literary works by creator Ian Fleming become open for public use
